captions.text:
So last time we
got together I was

talking about the
challenge line.

Comfort, challenge, comfort,
challenge, comfort, challenge.

Now today we're going to be
talking about 'fraidy cats.

Raising them up, pushing
them over that line,

letting them know it's
better on the other side.
Are you psyched?
Because I am, man.
Let's talk 'fraidy cats.
One, two, let's get catified.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

Let's talk about
how we get our cats
to go from 'fraidy to mojo.

First thing is your best
friend and min, right here,
it's basically painter's tape.

And the coolest
thing about blue tape

is that as you can
see it's sticky

but it doesn't
stick really, right?

So you can put it on
the furniture here.
You can put it on your guitar.

You can put it on your forehead
and you can take it right off.

Every time you've identified
your cats challenge line

you put one of these
suckers on the floor.

Now we know that today we're
going to put a bowl of food
right there on that line.

Tomorrow, we're going
to reset that line,

and I don't even care
if it's by three inches.

But we are going to get
her to start coming out.

As we're moving the cats
through challenge line work,

further and further
out, a couple things
we're going to do.

First thing we're going
to do is gradually

block off the places that
they're calling home.

In order for them to be that
best version of themselves

we've got to say, you
know what, I will give you

all the love that you
could possibly desire,

all the comfort that you
need, but not under there.

Block off a little
bit of that under.

Alright, I'm not saying that
one day your cat wakes up

and you have shoved
pillows underneath the bed,

or you have removed
the under of the bed.

It's something that
happens gradually, right?

Now, as your cat has cleared
that first initial challenge

line, now we start
bringing out the toys, man.

And again the toys that have
the rods, the fishing pole toys,

the ones with feathers,
or mice at the end.
Those toys.

Really crucial if they
move towards the middle

of that floor and they
kill, when I say kill,
they pounce on that toy.

That from that moment
on, they own that spot.

And we know that the
key to mojo is what?
Ownership of territory.
Ownership of territory.
Boom, cat mojo supreme.

And we have taken a wall
flower and turned them

into the best version of
themselves that they can be.
Now a bit of a disclaimer.

I'm not talking about
morphing your cat into someone
they're not.

Don't expect your cat
to be someone else.

Expect you cat to be the
best version of themselves
that they can be.
And that's our job.

To start realizing that
every time she pokes her out

from under that bed,
good things happen.
Don't feed under the bed.

It is not doing your cat
any favors whatsoever.

If they know that at some point
you are just going to cave

and you are going to put
food in their hiding zone?

Again, not doing
them any favors.
Now that's the truth, Ruth.
So your homework is as follows.

Number one, lead
them out with food
and the challenge line of tape.

The second thing
you're going to do

is block off the
unders very slowly.

Every day a little bit more
of that challenge line pushed.

And the third
thing is, make sure

through interactive play
and the replication of hunt,

catch, kill, eat that you
get that mojo unleashed.

The mojo gets unleashed,
the wall flower
comes out of hiding.
Alright folks, that's it for me.

Don't forget, find
me anywhere, man.

I'm on Twitter, instagram,
Facebook, where else,
Google plus, YouTube.

And don't forget
with your homework,
share it with the rest of us.

The only way that we're
all going to learn

is through discussion,
conversation,
group revelations.

Hashtag TeamCatMojo, that way
I'll see it, we'll all see it.
Follow that conversation.

Because remember something,
folks, if you make a discovery

and you give it to the rest
of us we can save lives.
It is that simple.
It is.
All right until next time folks.

All light, all love
and all mojo to you.
Love you.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

title: 3 Steps To Make Your Cat More Social

Blocking of a spot to hide is a big mistake. The best thing to do from my 
experience is to let them come out from their own, and if they do so - 
leave the cat alone. if you ignore the cat instead of staring at it as it 
comes out your cat will feel alot more comfortable.﻿

my old cat was very Social she never bit me or scratcht me ever and she was

comments.author: catfolt

comments.text:
I have a cat that will be 6 this year. I took her Mom in and she was born 
on my knees. I found good homes for her 7 brothers and sisters but decided 
to keep her. I have been like her Mother from the beginning and that's how 
she treats me. She grooms me, she always runs to me when she is scared, she 
would be lost without me. The problem is, that I have not been able to 
socialize her with other people in the last 6 years. I live alone and don't 
have a lot of company, but when I do, she runs and hides and will not come 
out until long  after they are gone. I have 3 other cats too, one of them 
is her bio Mom, and they are all socialized. She has no problem owning the 
house, as a matter of fact, she is the alpha cat here. Do you have any 
suggestions, please???﻿
comments.author: Wendy Boissevain

comments.text:
I have brought my cat from a shelter and he gets scared very easily. After 
watching your video I have put some masking tapes on his hidding places and 
he is playing with the tapes. I think he thinks it's a game. Is this 
working??﻿
comments.author: Min jeong Kang

comments.text:
I got my cat a new toy and he's acting weird now. He starts hissing and 
growling at it and his tail puffs up. I dont know if he's afraid of it or 
not. Should I be concerned?﻿
comments.author: Zoie Bryan

comments.text:
My cats name is Butter, she is currently 5 years old turning 6, we did not 
buy her or adopt her she starting coming to our house one day she didnt 
have a collar nor any ear markings or anything visible we fed her and let 
her look around the house after a couple of visits and then she moved in 
with us, we were okay with it cus we thought she was homeless but in case 
we took her to this cat place and we were told she lived very close by and 
we contacted the owners. Butter had been the most wonderful cat while she 
was staying at ours at first she was a little shy and didnt know our place 
that well but thats normal she had been with us for just 2 weeks but the 
moment she even heard her owner voice she didnt even see them or smell them 
(at least I think, they were in the hallway a couple of meters away from 
the bedroom she was resting in) she freaked out and hid under the bed and 
was basically in every sense a wallflower cat, we then learned he was a 
mother and had been forced to live with her 1 and a half year old son and 
she had escaped home the owners gave her too us not long after that because 
she chose to live with us and they understood.
But now its been almost 2 years since that and every now and then if she 
gets a little to exited or if I get a little to exited around her or 
sometimes just randomly she flees and hides under the bed and if anyone 
stand around the bed for too long she will attack your feet, it doesnt 
usually last longer than 10 minutes. I dont really know what to do, I dont 
play with her when she is doing that because that makes her act like that 
for a longer time (we have another play area and thats not it) and I wont 
give her treats under the bed cause i dont want to promote her behaviour 
but I would really like to know what to do since i dont think this is 
healthy behaviour.﻿
comments.author: sandratail

comments.text:
My cat doesn't really like to play, except with my laser pointer. But I 
heard so different stuff about it, what's your thoughts? Can I use the 
laser pointer or is it hurting on some kind his psyche?﻿
comments.author: Terror Kruemel

comments.text:
I'd like someone's opinion please. I have quite a skittish little cat who 
always sleeps in my bedroom upstairs. She gets along well enough with most 
of my other cats but she never ever comes down the stairs and becomes very 
stressed whenever I carry her down. I know she feels safe and comfortable 
in my room but I imagine it can get pretty lonely being up there all the 
time. I'd love it if she would join my and my other furry friends 
downstairs once in a while but I don't want to force her. I want her to be 
more social but I dunno if locking her out of my room is really the best 
way to do it...﻿
comments.author: Erin Delic

comments.text:
I think the last thing you would want to do is lock your cat out from her 
safe zone. That would probably stress her out even more. If you have her 
food in your bedroom, try moving it down into your living room (assuming 
that's a more social area for your cats). This would get her to come out of 
hiding, but still on her own terms.
comments.author: Kaylin Ens

comments.text:
Hello. I have a car very very shy but We Want a other cat and We don't Know

other cat so much and he's just a kitten. Why is she losing her mono, she's

I think the best way to get your cat to come out and stay out is to treat

comments.author: Arthur Frentzel

comments.text:
Jackson

I have a cat named Apricot. Her story is as follows, from my perspective. 
My dad's co-worked is riding around a wasteyard one day, and happens to see 
an orange and white cat, and takes him in. Two weeks later, She gives him 
away, as he is attacking her other cat. At this time he was only around 
eight and a half weeks old. I then adopt her, and my brother and I decide 
we should introduce him to the other cat, named Oreo, or at least thats 
what I call her. So then, she gets closer, and Apricot flings his claws at 
her. Thirteen weeks later now, he won't even get near her, and I have no 
clue why. I've given many tries to make him interact with her, and he just 
wont, and keeps attacking her for reasons I don't know. Once again, I've 
already tried taking baby steps, Every day for the past few weeks now, I 
have taken tiny steps towards getting him to interact. He just wont, plain 
and simple

Please help with this, Or link a video in a reply that will help me.﻿
comments.author: The Minecraft Pro

comments.text:
I should have watched this when we brought our Humphrey home at the end of 
June.  Mistakes were made. Nov 2 was the first day that he did not retreat 
to his safe spot under the bed. I know he will be less social than the 
other kitties (especially with strangers), but he is very social and loving 
with us. I have been using positive reinforcement when he is with us in the 
social area. Lots of play and treats with our other 2 cats. Thanks for all 
of the good info!﻿
comments.author: Liz Pearson

comments.text:
#teamcatmojo  Hello Jackson, hello fellow cat-lovers, I just recently 
adopted my neighbor's cat because he developed an allergy against cat hair 
after having her for nearly two years - tragic I know - . She is in my 
place since saturday and I knew she was a fraidy cat. At first she was 
hiding under a blanket being just a kitty bump, but she came out from time 
to time and now on the third day, I can play with her and even pet her a 
little. My problem is that her flea treatment is due in three days and I'm 
really afraid she is going to scratch me or run away and all the progress 
we made will be gone. Do you have any tips on how to make the anti-flea 
spot-on treatment easier for a newly arrived fraidy cat? btw. I haven't 
found her jackpot-treat yet. All the treats I presented her were just 
ignored :(﻿

comments.author: Carol Reid

comments.text:
I was fostering a cat that's become mine by default. After 7 months I've 
got her confident enough to play around the house, play with the other cat 
who she adores but she still won't let me or anyone else come within 3 feet 
of her. For all these months she's been here I haven't been able to pet 
her, clip her nails, touch her. How do I get my fraidy cat over the next 
hurdle and allow some human contact?﻿
comments.author: Deborah Alexander

comments.text:
I would be curious if you have any success here. I have a similar case, 
except I've had mine 6 years. (No, seriously.) He and his "sister" came to 
my apartment as fosters at about 5 months of age. They were very 
unsocialized. I was patient with them, and eventually, the female warmed to 
me. I decided to keep both of them. Now, the female is extremely 
affectionate (borderline needy), though still shy and hesitant around 
strangers (I don't consider this a problem). The male, on the other hand, 
won't let me make physical contact. If I try, he hisses and runs away. And 
I'm not talking attempts to grab him. This is just simple gentle petting. 
The most contact I ever get is that I can occasionally hold out my hand to 
him and he will cautiously sniff it. (Then he quickly backs away.) He does 
walk openly around my apartment, and will even often sleep on the couch 
about 1 1/2 feet from me (the end closest to the door, of course - it's 
where he is as I type this). Play therapy doesn't seem to work, or the 
progress is WAY too slow. Bribing with treats/food hasn't helped. I tried 
putting him on meds, but they were just too expensive and too difficult to 
administer, for a variety of reasons. I have mostly resigned myself to 
having one cat and one feline freeloading roommate. So, if anyone has any 
tips, I'd love to hear them. It makes me sad that this creature that I just 
want to love should live in so much fear of coming into physical contact 
with me.
comments.author: HeathMaiden

comments.text:
Jackson, I'd love your advice on the beautiful black Angora feral who lives 
mostly in my back yard.  After three years, I have gotten her to take food 
from my fingers, but I have stroked her only once.  She likes to come 
inside and investigate, but runs outside again if a noise startles her.  (I 
don't encourage her to come in, btw, because of possible parasites; but she 
has done, sometimes.)  I am going to have to move household in the coming 
year, and I worry where she will find food.﻿
comments.author: Fiona Kelleghan

comments.text:
Newbirth35, I also have a feral, who has come to be quite trusting, though 
it's taken seven months.  Jackson is right: "gradually" is the key word for 
frightened cats, and even for assured ones.  (My bf is theatrical and often 
bursts into song or flails around, illustrating some movie point, and he's 
"gradually" learning not to do this around the feral. Our other two cats 
don't care for the histrionics, either.)  ﻿
comments.author: Fiona Kelleghan

comments.text:
Im socializing my second cat now using nothing but feline language, TLC, 
and some soup meat from time to time. No challenging lines or anything. It 
works fine. The only thing that is important: Make sure that the hiding 
spots are such that they feel safe, but you can still easily approach them. 
Blink at them, look the other way sometimes. Make sure you are at their 
level when approaching them. And put their food bowls where they should be. 
They will come out of hiding when you're not around. ;-)﻿
comments.author: gammerlaan

comments.text:
Is there anything to be done to build a stronger / better bond between two 
cats?﻿
comments.author: Holly C (Rune)

comments.text: Mejuta﻿
comments.author: Juan Marcelo Avalos

comments.text:
My cat is a hunter, so she's quite confident. She's what we call 
predictably unpredictable. We know she's unpredictable, which is what make 
her predictable. In the 10 years we've had her I've never seen her give off 
many signs at all when she's going to pounce. But, since we put our other 
cat down in March Cali, the cat that's still with us, has calmed down 
dramatically. And they never liked each other one bit. They just learned to 
tolerate each other.﻿
comments.author: AngelWingsTV

comments.text:
This method works! I adopted a rescue 3 month old kitten from my 
veterinarian. He was very fearful at first, so we let him get adjusted to 
sight, sounds, smells in my small family room for a few days. He would come 
out briefly to eat and would play at night. Little by little, we moved his 
"stuff" further away from the sofa area which he hid under. Within about 2 
weeks...he was out, plays anytime, answers to his name when called, and is 
as affectionate and happy as can be. When he went back to the vet for his 
shots and checkup, even the vet was surprised at how comfortable and tame 
this kitten had become! Thanks, Jackson!﻿
comments.author: KerryGrl

comments.text:
I have a cat named ashes she has black hair and wight on her chest when she 
sees me she runs but my other cat Amos loves me﻿
comments.author: seattleseahawks bro

comments.text:
My cat Reine is friendly and lovable BUT she's afraid of new people. She 
can get used to them after several hours have passed, but she's hiding from 
them. I don't know why and I'm not sure how to help her with that problem. 
Any suggestions?﻿
comments.author: kittygirlnya

comments.text:
Around 19 years ago, we got a cat from the shelter. She was incredibly 
afraid. The first three weeks, she would not get from under the couch. Me 
and my sister decided to wrap some feathers on a stick at that point, and 
we started luring her out from underneath the ouch to play. It only took us 
about six months to be able to do absolutely everything with her. She loved 
belly rubs, and you could basically swing her around your neck for a real 
life fur scarf, haha [she actually loved that]. She also really loved 
hunting. We got quite a big backyard. In the summer, she'd kill and bring 
us around 60 to 70 mice a week. Sadly she died, but she was rather old 
though. She really was a very sweet cat. Really nice to see how much you 
can do with just a little bit of time :3﻿
comments.author: SnowyMuffin

comments.text:
I had a fraidy cat once. Took me three weeks to turnhim into a mojo. Its 
easy really. All it takes is patience and some decent communication. Its a 
lot of fun to work with these fraidy cats..
﻿
comments.author: gammerlaan

comments.text:
Great advice, but we have 14 cats in a small house, 2 are very skiddish, 
not sure it will work with so many cats in a small townhome, plus have 
rabbits & dog﻿
comments.author: charles murray

comments.text:
Figured Id post something on one of my two boys.  99% of the time 
everything is 'normal' in how he acts however when he hears loud noises 
(usually from the TV), he goes running to the other room.  It could simply 
be a commercial on the TV that causes this, and is especially true when I 
watch an action movie.  Its just odd because my other cat has no problems 
with any of this (heck he can sleep through machine gun fire on tv) and 
also my kitty with the issue wasn't like this when we was younger. Hes 5 
now but I would say he got like this in the past 2 year or so.  Any 
suggestions? Thanks﻿
comments.author: RoachForLife

comments.text:
Should I push my senior cat beyond her comfort zone? She isn't so skittish 
that she hides. She has always been skittish with everyone But me (I've had 
her since she was 2 days old) Now, at 18 years, she has decided to live on 
the couch pretty much all the time. She has to go into the bathroom for 
water (there's some closer, but she doesn't like it) and for a litter box, 
but she eats on the couch (a certain little kitty likes to chase her if she 
eats out of the other bowls, though not maliciously). She's mostly blind, 
she can see large things and movement. 
She loves to sit on my lap and be petted, but she Only gets off the couch 
to drink and use the litter box and then only when the other cats are 
sleeping or where she can't see them.
So, since she is so very old, how much do I push her? Or do I let the 
little old lady do as she pleases?﻿
comments.author: Temperance Garrison

comments.text:
Interesting method of behaviour modification. I'm sure it works.

I guess the 'fraidy' bit, at least for me, can be somewhat deeper.. Any 
behaviour usually has a reason. And it behooves us to look for the why.

We adopted a one year old cat from the Humane Society two years ago for my 
son. He picked her out. We already had a senior cat (Cotton_) at home 
(who's 17 now, and with the power of arithmetic, was 15 years old then).She 
had been living as the solo cat in the house when one of my daughters 
graduated from school in 2005 and took her cat with her. Yes, nine years of 
being a solo cat. 

At first, new fur baby (Blair) stayed with son, upstair, and we gradually 
introduced her to the rest of the house. She would run away at the 
slightest noise, hated being picked up  or held and was deathly afraid of 
Cotton, who even if Cotton turned in her direction, Blair would scatter.

We suspected perhaps, besides a new environment, she had had some trauma or 
mistreatment. Maybe not.

Blair would let me stroke her, but only at arms length, with access to a 
quick get away. If anyone crossed her path, she'd run in the opposite 
direction.

I took things at her speed. She didn't share the food and water bowl with 
Cotton, but rather, they took (and continue to take) turns. She graduated 
to jumping up on the arm my easy chair to get stroked, She had plenty of 
climbing room. The two cats settled into different areas. For example, 
Blair would sit and relax on the sofa and Cotton would sit on my chair.

Cotton would sleep at my side on my bed and Blair would be at the foot of 
the bed,

Now, Blair will gingerly place a paw on my lap as she descends from the arm 
of the chair, till she slowly stands, then sits, then finally lays her 
little head down, completely relaxed. I'm gently stroking her the entire 
time and she becomes a purr baby. Still. someone walking by can spook her 
and she's gone.

She loves chasing balled up paper and balls (but not noisy ones). She runs 
away from feathers on a stick.

As long as I approach her slowly and offer my hand, she'll hang out and 
play, She even will follow me from time to time. ﻿
comments.author: imaof4

comments.text:
Jackson, thank you for your show and your advice. I have two rescues named 
Sammy and Sara I adopted almost seven years ago now. They are very social 
and comfortable with other cats but a human just has to look at them too 
long from across the room to send them scurrying under the bed in terror.
After all these years with my own work, I can now pet them easily and I 
feel they've been a great success story. I'm looking forward to taking what 
I've been learning from you to help bring them out of their shell even 
more, hopefully they can learn to accept strangers or go for a walk. 
Anyway, thank you.﻿
comments.author: TarlaPrettyPaws

comments.text: Man, you are getting skinny!﻿
comments.author: Ann Bermingham

comments.text:
Hello my name is Rachel, I just started watching your show and I love it. 
My cat Cotton was found abandoned at 5 and half months three years ago. He 
is a Turkish Angora. Cotton is a cave dweller whenever there are people 
over. I have refer to him as a scaredy cat. When it is just the two of us 
he is mostly a beach dweller. What can I do to help him be less afraid of 
people? 

Thank you for what you do.﻿
comments.author: Rachel Bishop

comments.text: How do you prevent cat from climbing up sliding screen door?﻿
comments.author: Carol Ramos

comments.text:
My cat is sorta shy... She is comfortable with just me and her in the home, 
sleeps in the open, plays and comes to me for contact. But a knock on the 
door and a person coming in, sends her in hiding, where she stays untill 1. 
she sees it is a person that have been here some times before. 2. Nothing 
is really happening, but me and the guest talking. 3 The person leaves 
again. I am not really concerned about her hiding like that in those 
situations, seeing that she comes back out, if she sees that nothing is 
happening and that the time she is hiding is shorter if she gets to know a 
regular guest. ﻿

comments.text:
rofl cant believe people have this problem. When I was young and him too I 
used to train mr kitty to jump up high by putting up high places like the 
kitchen bench and table thinking "see kitty you are super kitty, dont be 
afraid to jump up here ^_^" ... he never really got the hang of it... maybe 
to him it just wasnt high enough.... he could jump way higher than that :D 
he was probably like the fuck is this excuse me while i go play on the 
roof.﻿

comments.text:
Hello Jackson, I always watch your shows and love them I have 3 cats and 2 
dogs that get along very well I adopted them all but a month ago my brother 
abandoned his indoor cat outside and he is gone most of the time for 2 or 3 
weeks at his girlfriends and no one feeds this poor cat so I adopted her 
this is where I need your advice she also is one of my cats sister she is 
about 8 years old they were both feral kittens but my male cat is very 
affectionate now but the female that I just adopted is scared of people and 
always in hiding but not aggressive its the 2nd day now in a separate room 
the 2nd night she was crying during the night so I slept on the floor and 
she came to me and let me pet her and she was very affectionate but she 
kept crying even while I was petting her and giving her food and this 
morning it was like nothing happened she is still in hiding and she is not 
interested in toys,when my brother had her I think the only affection she 
had from him was food,please give me advice how to socilize her﻿
comments.author: Marie Racciopoli

comments.text:
I don't know how many of these you actually have time to look at, but I do 
have a question (anyone reading comments please feel free to answer too) I 
volunteer at an animal shelter where I live (all cats) and there is this 
one super sweet cat, who isn't so sweet with the other cats, or even most 
other people. She has spent almost a half hour calm and sitting in my lap 
purring, and is one of the most affectionate girl cats I know. With me and 
two other volunteers. She is easily overwhelmed, the other cats terrify her 
or make her jealous, and most new people she can't be bothered with, or 
she'll hiss at them. This is a no kill shelter, so I am not afraid of her 
being put down, but she needs a home (not in financial position to take her 
and will NOT take an animal under my care I cannot keep!). How do I make 
everyone else see the sweetheart she really is? Suggestions?﻿
comments.author: Maeve La Fey

comments.text:
I don't know how to change her behaviour, but we video shy cats when they 
are playing and cuddling, and put it with their picture on the animal 
shelter's  website, to show that the cat does actually play and cuddle.

Sounds like once adopted she will be fine as she will have time to get used 
to her owners and trust them like she trusts you.

comments.text: Come down those stairs he would run﻿

comments.author: Ghoster5671

comments.text:
Jackson, we adopted a 5 month old from a shelter. He was in a foster home 
before the shelter. He is terrified of strangers in our home, particularly 
men. But he also growls, crouches and runs, when he sees a neighbor woman 
and her little girl come outside. At times, if he doesn't recognize my 
husband he runs from him. So Ken has started talking to him as soon as he 
comes in, and he has taken to picking him up, before bed time, talking, and 
petting him and then giving him a few treats. He is now 2 years old, I play 
with him for an hour after supper, and he waits and watches for this. He is 
starting to play like a normal cat, by himself, which he never did. And we 
built him a high tower, that he can jump and climb up and nap or just 
watch.  But if we have company, he's nowhere to be seen. We occasionally 
have family down( here in FL) from the north, and about the 5th day he will 
finally come out at night, and observe them. Only once did he allow my 
adult daughter to touch him. He does not like to be held, won't sit on our 
lap, but will lay on the top of the couch, above my head. What can I do to 
get him to not be terrified of strangers.﻿
comments.author: Sue Wicihowski

comments.text: iN THE RELIGION OF CAT-THLICKS,YOU  ARE SAINT JACKOSN! AL AL AM!﻿
comments.author: HEYWARD WHEATON

comments.text:
One of my cats (I have 8) only lets you touch her when she wants you to. I 
have had her since she was a kitten and she is now 2.5 years old. I have 
done the play thing, a challenge because the other cats jump in. I do the 
slow blink. She no longer runs when I come near her. But if I go to touch 
her, she is gone. If I have cheese, she is my best friend, again its on her 
terms. Some times I will look down and she will be close by. Recently after 
coming home from major surgery, I awoke in my recliner and saw her watching 
me from the arm of the recliner. Once I fully opened my eyes she left. I 
think she was making sure I was ok.

The other week she found herself trapped under a recliner. After hearing 
her growl, I tracked down where it was coming from and slowly opened the 
chair. She bolted down stairs. She was done there a long time, and I became 
concerned and went to check her. Found her hiding. But she did not run when 
I knelt down near her. She allowed me to pet her and eventually pick her 
up. All the time talking softly to her. She didn't want to be held any 
longer than a couple of minutes, and I let her go as I did not want to 
spook her.  As I was not able to fully check her legs, I found her a short 
while later and she was not able to leave the bathroom where she was (I 
shut the door). She jumped to the counter and while she was nervous she let 
me check her out fully. But she did not try to get away, or growl.

She hasn't let me pet her since, she is back to her old self. I guess my 
ration of being able to pet and pick her up is every 2.5 years.  I wish I 
knew how to get her to let me pet her and show her how much I love her. But 
I know it has to be on her terms. Has anyone else had a cat like my 
Tinkerbell? I am sure I am not the only one.﻿
comments.author: squirrel1ification

comments.text:
I've got a sweet tuxedo cat who's incredibly shy, but only around other 
people.  He adores me, and is completely normal if I'm the only one home.  
But if anyone else comes over, he's gone. Pizza guy knocked on the door, 
and I came downstairs to see the back half of my cat sliding under the 
couch. My friends typically come over on Friday night, and after nearly two 
years he at least makes a brief appearance to drink some water but he won't 
approach anyone at all.  Anything I can do to help him out, or should I 
just keep letting him be?﻿

comments.author: sock684

comments.author: Jennifer Zack

comments.text:
This sounds a lot like the process of working with the semi-feral I found 
on the side of the highway this winter. He spent 3 weeks hiding under a gap 
in the basement floor and leaving behind messes with worms in them before I 
decided to trap him to get veterinary care. After that, I used my giant 
husky crate to make him a safe space. It took months for him to get to the 
point where he would come to the door of his hidey hole for a bit of soft 
food or chopped up chicken. Once he was healthy enough to get fixed, we 
finally turned a corner.

After months of infinitesimal steps, Macavity started to come out for food 
when the door was open, and then would eat while I sat right beside him. 
Finally he let me give a pet or two while scarfing the food. Two months 
after turning the corner, he is a full member of the house, loves being 
petted and sleeps at my feet every night. I had been nearly ready to give 
up, wondering if I was doing the right thing, and it is amazing to see the 
change. I had hoped for handleable, and I got a cuddle cat.

Nature works on its own time. It's easy to be impatient and want to push 
too far, too fast. The first time he head butted my chin and started 
marking me was a moment that was worth waiting all those months for.﻿
comments.author: TheGFeather

comments.text:
Jackson, I just moved to a new state, my part-time 2.5 year old outdoor 
cats are now complete indoor cats. My roommate/owner of the house says they 
are not allowed in the living room/kitchen, so right now they are stuck in 
my bedroom with access to the bathroom. I can build them a catio on the 
patio, BUT I recently tried to take them outside in a kitty tent. They 
freaked. They tried to escape. They reacted to every little noise. The AC 
units nearby did not help. Once I've made the catio, I'm planning on 
putting out their bed, some grass, their small scratching post, and a 
blanket they use. However, I'm thinking of putting a box out there so they 
can hide if need be. Wise or unwise?﻿

comments.text:
My ultra shy Egyptian Mau has become way more sociable since I moved her 
cat tree to the living room. She's even demanding that my brother pet her 
where before he was lucky to get a glimpse of her. However, she is easily

comments.text:
I have a 3 year old male that I got as an 8 week old kitten.  He was so 
open to people at first.  HOWEVER, at the same time I had a feral fraidy 
cat who always ran even if she heard a car in the driveway.  Of course he 
took after her, even though she was NOT the dominate female in the house.So 
now we have Henry who is spooked by anything-even a cough. We built a 
CATIO.  Two of the females love it; I cannot get the male to go out side 
and even try it.  This is the second summer and he still will go up to the 
door, but will not go out.  How do lure him outside?  I cannot leave the 
door open.   I bait him with a  STRING TOY and he chewed off the cord.    I 
bait him with his favorite treats; he is too smart and knows he doesn't eat 
anywhere but in the kitchen.  So he will NOT come into the room with the 
Catio.  Do I just toss him on the  Catio and listen to him howl?  I do not 
want to do that.  The Catio is very nicely equipped .  The other two cats 
lay in the sun and eat cat-nip plants.  How do I get HENRY to go outside?﻿

comments.text:
#TeamCatMojo I have a 10 months old persian cat. And lately he stopped 
using his litter box and started peeing everywhere. He's not spraying he's 
peeing. Cuz I saw him doing it. And it started after he got in heat. We 
brought him a female cat but nothing happened and he was back to normal 
after a month of spraying. But then he started peeing. My parents are 
getting so annoyed and they want to give him away. But I just can't give up 
on him he's like my little baby and I can't imagine life without him. My 
mom said if he pee one more time she'll give him to the shelter and I've 
been running after him everywhere hoping he won't pee. His litter is always 
clean and in it's usual place.

We don't have kids to annoy him or scare him so he's always relaxed. We 
never yell at him or punish him even when he pee. And he's an indoor cat 
and only go out to the garden for an hour a day with me watching him. He 
eat (whiskas) wet food and finish one can a day

Please please help me I don't want to lose my cat :( 

(P.s: he's been drugged 3 times and had a surgery in his paw)﻿
comments.author: eleanor  ALAA

comments.text: Ow do you get a cat to like a dog more﻿
comments.author: connor momsen

comments.text:
Great suggestions!  We just adopted a new kitty about 2 months ago.  She 
was nervous but still quite loving for the most part, until she found a 
hiding spot under the bed.  If we blocked off the bedroom she would explore 
and be less skiddish, but as soon as she had access to the bed again she 
would hide and rarely come out!  We started only allowing her bedroom 
access at night when we were asleep, and over time she hid less and less 
the more she was able to explore and be around us enough to know we were 
not there to harm her.  She still hides under there now some (she still has 
issues with us walking towards her, she has to come to us!), but most of 
her sleep time is now ON the bed instead of under it!  I thank Jackson for 
his many Cat Mojo tips to help our progress.  :-)﻿
comments.author: Stephanie Cleary

comments.text:

comments.text:
I'd like to know what to do when your cat just suddenly gets skittish. My 
little cat Mina has suddenly gotten scared of every little sound. I was in 
hospital for 33 days back in Jan-Feb. but she was ok when I came home. But 
the last couple of weeks, she doesn't want to be held, she won't come play 
at bedtime and she runs and hides if you try to pick her up. Nothing has 
happened to her, she just started acting weird. I'm using treats to get her 
to come out in the living room with us and her big brother kitty Duke. 
She's still bullying Duke so it can't be something he did. They still share 
food bowls like they've always done. She just jumps at everything and won't 
let us hold her. She won't get in anyone's lap either. HELP!!!!!! What do I 
do?﻿
comments.author: Cindy Bird

comments.text:
It could be new cats outside your home that have started coming around and 
marking around the house, or she may be sensing a shift in your 
demeanor/emotions/attitude recently.  There could also be a health issue 
with her as well that may need to be checked out.  Try to rule out any 
changes or issues one at a time.
comments.author: Stephanie Cleary

comments.text:
Thank you for this great resource! I learn from and about cats all the time

friend, even though she has shredded the underneath part of the dining room 
chairs. We allow her this indulgence because she is otherwise perfect. 
Jackson rocks!﻿

comments.author: Halamy

comments.text:
Jackson i have an important question for you. How does one get an abused 
cat to trust the other person? Weather it was abused by its owner the owner 
repented, felt bad wanted to build a better relationship cries himself to 
sleep at night wishing he'd treat his or her cat better, or if the cat was 
rescued from an abused home. Either or. How could each party correct the 
damage done?﻿
comments.author: classicgamelover1985

comments.text:
I've had abused cats in the past. What worked for me was making sure they 
saw me put the food in the bowl and then stroking them as they ate. They 
will run at first, but over time the cat sees you won't hurt them and they 
are getting something good at the same time. It builds the idea you are the 
good one who brings food. Try giving treats too. Show the treat, get the 
cat to come in the room with you then put it on the floor near you. 
Eventually you will be able to hand-feed treats which strengthens the bond. 
Just remember it takes a long time to get an abused animal to trust you.So 
give kitty as long as kitty needs for each step.
comments.author: Cindy Bird

comments.text:
IMO only loving kindness over time. Good luck to you in your endeavor, I 
truely hope you get a breakthru.  =)
